content: The Act titled "Tax Equity Act of 2017" includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates. The Tax Equity Act of 2017 introduces regional cost-of-living adjustments to individual income tax rates starting after 2017. The rate table for taxable years will be further adjusted based on minimum and maximum dollar amounts. The Tax Equity Act of 2017 introduces regional cost-of-living adjustments to individual income tax rates starting after 2017. The rate table for taxable years will be adjusted based on minimum and maximum dollar amounts, with adjustments made to reflect the statistical area where the individual's primary residence is located. If any amount determined is not a multiple of $50, it will be rounded to the nearest multiple. The Tax Equity Act of 2017 introduces regional cost-of-living adjustments to individual income tax rates. The Secretary determines applicable multipliers for each statistical area of the United States annually. Multipliers are based on cost-of-living differentials, with adjustments made for areas exceeding 125 percent. The Tax Equity Act of 2017 introduces regional cost-of-living adjustments to individual income tax rates. The Secretary determines applicable multipliers for each statistical area of the United States annually based on cost-of-living differentials. The multiplier is 1.05 for areas with a cost-of-living differential between 97% and 125%, and for other areas, the multiplier is the cost-of-living differential for the calendar year. The Secretary of Labor determines and publishes a cost-of-living index for each statistical area annually based on average market prices. The index is calculated for the 12-month period ending on August 31 of the calendar year. The cost-of-living index is determined annually by the Secretary of Labor for each statistical area based on market prices. The index is calculated for the 12-month period ending on August 31 of the calendar year, using the same methodology as the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers. The term 'statistical area' includes metropolitan statistical areas defined by the Secretary of Commerce and portions of states not within those areas. Outside the United States, the area multiplier is 1. The amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2017, with a multiplier of 1 for areas outside the United States.
